title: Overview
text: This website is designed for the NM2207 course project about data visualization.  It is intended solely for educational purposes, without any profit motive.  For more details, please use the drop-down menu!!!!

title: Overview
text:
About the Author
My name is Yolanda Liu Xingyan, a Year 2 Communications and New Media student studying at the National University of Singapore. My career objective is to leverage digital tools to craft impactful marketing campaigns. My journey with digital tools begins with this course.

title: Overview
text:
Contact Information
If you have any questions, feedback, or suggestions for topics you would like to see covered on this website, please feel free to contact me at xingyanliu10@u.nus.edu.

title: About
text: About this site

title: Overview
text:
Dataset Focused on
The data source I have curated is the Drug Consumption dataset provided by University of California, Irvine UCI Dataset. It documents the consumption habits of 1885 respondents across 18 legal or illegal drugs such as alcohol, amphetamines, amyl nitrite, benzodiazepine, cannabis, chocolate, cocaine, caffeine, crack, ecstasy, heroin, ketamine, legal highs, LSD, methadone, mushrooms, nicotine, volatile substance abuse, and a fictitious drug named Semeron.




Fehrman, Elaine, Egan, Vincent, and Mirkes, Evgeny. (2016). Drug Consumption (Quantified). UCI Machine Learning Repository. https://doi.org/10.24432/C5TC7S.

title: Overview

Why Website
Website serves as an accessible platform for disseminating information to a broad audience, aligning with the expansive reach of the ‚ÄúSay No to Drugs‚Äù goal in this project.

title: Overview

About
My name is Yolanda Liu Xingyan, a Year 2 Communications and New Media student studying at the National University of Singapore. My career objective is to leverage digital tools to craft impactful marketing campaigns. My journey with digital tools begins with this course.

title: Research Question
text:
Research Question
How do demographic characteristics, socioeconomic status, and psychological traits influence the frequency and type of drug consumption?

title: Research Question
section: Why This Data Analysis is Important?
text:
Why This Data Analysis is Important?

According to Saah (2005), addiction is often triggered by the natural reward system‚Äôs conversion of ‚Äúliking‚Äù into ‚Äúwanting,‚Äù emphasizing the importance of addressing drug use issues due to their addictive nature, which can result in persistent challenges in quitting.
Strickland & Smith (2014) outlined the influence of social context on individuals‚Äô propensity towards drug use, thus analyzing personal experiences (e.g., demography, personality) and drug use can tailor intervention strategies to prevent or mitigate drug-related harm before addiction.
According to Fox et al.¬†(2013), drug abusers are estimated to commit millions of drug-motivated crimes annually; therefore, developing preemptive strategies to address drug use can enhance public safety and alleviate the societal burden associated with drug-related offenses.


Reference List

Fox, T. P., Oliver, G., & Ellis, S. M. (2013). The destructive capacity of drug abuse: an overview exploring the harmful potential of drug abuse both to the individual and to society. ISRN Addiction, 2013, 450348. https://doi.org/10.1155/2013/450348
Saah (2005) Saah T. (2005). The evolutionary origins and significance of drug addiction. Harm reduction journal, 2, 8. https://doi.org/10.1186/1477-7517-2-8
Strickland & Smith (2014) Strickland, J. C., & Smith, M. A. (2014). The effects of social contact on drug use: behavioral mechanisms controlling drug intake. Experimental and clinical psychopharmacology, 22(1), 23‚Äì34. https://doi.org/10.1037/a0034669

Research Question
How do demographic characteristics and psychological traits (i.e., personality) influence the frequency and type of drug consumption?

title: Research Question
text: This section delineates the focal points of this data story, including the central question it aims to address and the significance of this inquiry within the context of my course project.

title: Demographic Characteristics [Univariate Analysis]
text:
How does each demographic characteristic affect the drug consumption patterns?
This univariate analysis page will feature an analysis of four key demographic factors: Age, Gender, Education Level, and Country. The aim is to elucidate their relationship with drug consumption patterns. For reference: CL0 indicating ‚Äònever used‚Äô, CL1 representing ‚Äòused over a decade ago‚Äô, CL2 indicating ‚Äòused in the last decade‚Äô, CL3 indicating ‚Äòused in the last year‚Äô, CL4 representing ‚Äòused in the last month‚Äô, CL5 indicating ‚Äòused in the last week‚Äô, and CL6 representing ‚Äòused in the last day‚Äô.  Note: This dataset contains 1766 participants, with 905 females and 861 males.

title: Research Question
text:
Variables Included
Independent Variables:



Demographic Characteristics
Psychological Traits




Age
Agreeableness (A)


Gender
Conscientiousness (C)


Education
Extraversion (E)


Country
Neuroticism (N)



Openness to Experience (O)



Note:
1) The gender list only consists of binary entries, chosen for simplicity.
2) The education list includes the following entries: Left school before 16 years, Left school at 16 years, Left school at 17 years, Left school at 18 years, Professional certificate/diploma, Some college or university, no certificate or degree, University degree, Master‚Äôs degree, Doctorate degree.
3) The list of countries includes six entries: The United States, The United Kingdom, Republic of Ireland, Australia, New Zealand, and Canada.

Dependent Variables:



Types of Drugs




Alcohol


Caffeine


Nicotine


Cannabis


Cocaine


Heroin



Note: The consumption of each drug is categorized into seven degrees, ranging from CL0 to CL6. These categories represent various usage frequencies, with CL0 indicating ‚Äònever used‚Äô, CL1 representing ‚Äòused over a decade ago‚Äô, CL2 indicating ‚Äòused in the last decade‚Äô, CL3 indicating ‚Äòused in the last year‚Äô, CL4 representing ‚Äòused in the last month‚Äô, CL5 indicating ‚Äòused in the last week‚Äô, and CL6 representing ‚Äòused in the last day‚Äô.

text:

Extraversion (E)

Neuroticism (N)



Openness to Experience (O)



Note:
1) The gender list only consists of binary entries, chosen for simplicity.
2) The education list includes the following entries: Left school before 16 years; Left school at 16 years; Left school at 17 years; Left school at 18 years; Some college or university, no certificate or degree; Professional certificate/diploma; University degree; Master‚Äôs degree; Doctorate degree.
3) The list of countries includes six entries: The United States, The United Kingdom, Republic of Ireland, Australia, New Zealand, and Canada.

Dependent Variables:



Types of Drugs




Alcohol


Caffeine


Nicotine


Cannabis


Cocaine


Heroin



Note:
1) The consumption of each drug is categorized into seven degrees, ranging from CL0 to CL6. These categories represent various usage frequencies, with CL0 indicating ‚Äònever used‚Äô, CL1 representing ‚Äòused over a decade ago‚Äô, CL2 indicating ‚Äòused in the last decade‚Äô, CL3 indicating ‚Äòused in the last year‚Äô, CL4 representing ‚Äòused in the last month‚Äô, CL5 indicating ‚Äòused in the last week‚Äô, and CL6 representing ‚Äòused in the last day‚Äô.
2) Drugs are categorized into three groups based on their legal status across six examined countries: legal drugs, controversial drugs, and illegal drugs. Legal drugs are those permitted in all six countries; controversial drugs are legal in some but not all countries; illegal drugs are prohibited across all six countries.   Specifically, Alcohol, Caffeine, and Nicotine fall under the classification of legal drugs, while Cannabis is categorized as a controversial drug. Cocaine and Heroin are classified as illegal drugs.

title: Psychological Traits  [Box Plot Analysis]
text:
How does personality affect the drug consumption patterns?
This page will present a box plot analysis examining the influence of scores obtained in five personality factors from the NEO-FFI-R questionnaire on patterns of drug consumption. The analyzed factors include Neuroticism (N Score), Extraversion (E Score), Openness to Experience (O Score), Agreeableness (A Score), and Conscientiousness (C Score). A higher score indicates a greater likelihood of experiencing specific feelings within each respective category.

title: Demographic Characteristics [Univariate Analysis]
text:
Legal Drugs
These three drugs (alcohol, cafeeine and nocotine) are legal in all 6 analyzed countries.

Alcohol
The majority of participants consume alcohol with some regularity, with monthly (CL4), weekly (CL5), or daily (CL6) consumption being the most reported.
Younger people consume more: Younger individuals are more likely to have engaged in alcohol consumption more recently, while older age groups show a higher frequency of alcohol consumption in the more distant past, with a notable decline in recent consumption as age progresses.
Minor gender difference: While overall gender differences in alcohol consumption appear minimal, there are specific points of divergence. Despite these variations, both genders display a similar pattern of alcohol consumption, with the majority having consumed alcohol at some stage and only a small proportion never having consumed alcohol at all.
Higher educational level might bring more consumption: The relationship between education and alcohol consumption is not strongly marked at the lower consumption levels or distant past (CL0 to CL3). Still, a trend emerges at the higher levels of recent alcohol use (CL4 to CL6), where individuals with higher education, such as university graduates, show a tendency towards more frequent alcohol consumption. Higher education may influence alcohol consumption habits, leading to more frequent use among these individuals.
Minor country difference: Alcohol consumption is a widespread phenomenon with similar levels of engagement across the countries surveyed, pointing to the absence of notable distinctions in alcohol consumption habits based on country.

Age
There is an observable overall decline in alcohol consumption as age increases. The proportion of individuals who have never consumed alcohol (CL0) diminishes with advancing age. The peak occurrence for those who last consumed alcohol over a decade ago (CL1) is found within the 45-54 age bracket. The age group most likely to have consumed alcohol in the last decade (CL2) is 35-44. For more recent consumption categories‚Äîconsumed in the last year (CL3), last month (CL4), last week (CL5), and last day (CL6)‚Äîthe majority are in the youngest age group, 18-24.







Gender
A smaller portion of the surveyed population, 16.68% of females and 19.05% of males, includes individuals who have never consumed alcohol (CL0) or those who last consumed alcohol up to a year ago (CL3). The overall data suggests that the difference in alcohol consumption patterns between genders is negligible. The largest observed difference is in the weekly consumption category (CL5), where 42.98% of females and 37.51% of males reported consumption, yet this difference is not considered significant.







Education







Country








Caffeine
Younger people consume more: Younger adults exhibiting more frequent usage. This trend suggests that caffeine consumption may decrease as individuals age, particularly after passing the 55-year mark.
Minor gender difference: Both males and females exhibit similar patterns of caffeine consumption, with both genders showing a high level of caffeine intake. There is no significant gender difference influencing the frequency of caffeine consumption.

Age
The data suggests that weekly (CL5) and daily (CL6) caffeine consumption is predominantly observed in the younger age brackets, specifically those aged 18-24 and 25-34. There is a noticeable decline in caffeine consumption among individuals in the 55-64 age group. Furthermore, the peak of caffeine consumption ‚Äòover a decade ago‚Äô (CL1) is most evident in the 35-44 age category, which aligns with the finding that caffeine consumption is most prevalent among those currently in the 18-24 and 25-34 age groups.







Gender
The majority of surveyed individuals consume caffeine either on a daily basis (CL6), with 24.64% female and 29.15% male respondents, or on a weekly basis (CL5), with 42.98% females and 37.51% males. However, the gender difference in caffeine consumption frequency is not significantly pronounced.

title: Conclusion
text:
Let‚Äôs review the research question first.
How do demographic characteristics and psychological traits (i.e., personality) influence the frequency and type of drug consumption?
Accordingly, this conclusion page will be divided into two distinct parts: one addressing demographic characteristics and the other focusing on psychological traits.
